In the first twelve chapters of the Basic Section, the Bodhisattva ParamÄrthasamudgata, before explaining this treatise, first establishes the meaning of three gates and then explains
the main text of the treatise.
As for the meaning of the three gates,
the first is the gate of paying homage, etc.

The first is to show that those who are attached to the wrong views of self and others held by non-Buddhists are not true.
The second is to allow them to cultivate merits and worldly dharmas without attachment.
The third is to encourage the cultivation and realization of all the factors conducive to liberation, such as firm and wonderful wisdom.
The fourth is to restrain and discourage the worldly dharmas that lead to decline, and to encourage one to stay far away from them.

The second approach is divided into three: the first verse shows the faults of waiting for the time and desires, etc., which is divided into three.

The third clarifies that those who do not understand the five desires will attract the fruits of sexual misconduct, while the sages do not attract them. The second and third verses show the proper principle of abandoning desires, etc., which is divided into three.

The second clarifies that since the disciples have no worries, they cultivate the pure life. If it is said that they still attract criticism, it is not reasonable.
